intro: Pilosocereus catingicola subsp. hapalacanthus, commonly known as the Catinga cactus, is a species native to Brazil, specifically the Catinga biome. It is a spiny, columnar cactus that typically grows in dry, rocky soils. The plant features a thick, ribbed stem with prominent spines, which help reduce water loss and provide protection from herbivores. Its flowers are usually yellow or white, appearing in clusters at the tips of the stems. This subspecies is adapted to arid conditions and plays a role in the local ecosystem by providing shelter and food for various animals.
